title: 108_hr1583
content: The "Occupational Safety and Health-Fairness Act of 2003" amends sections of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 related to contesting citations and willful violations. The "Occupational Safety and Health-Fairness Act of 2003" amends the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 regarding willful violations and the fairness of penalty assessment. Willful violations now require employers to knowingly disregard safety regulations or expose employees to hazards recklessly. Section 17(j) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to include factors such as the size and financial condition of the employer, the gravity of the violation, the employer's good faith efforts to comply, and the history of previous violations when assessing penalties. The amendment to Section 17(j) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 considers factors like employer size, financial condition, violation gravity, good faith efforts to comply, and past violations when determining penalties. Additionally, it takes into account previous violations by the employer at nonconstruction and construction worksites within the same state, as well as the level of responsibility for the violation. SEC. 5. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH REVIEW COMMISSION. Amendments to the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 include extending the term of a member until a successor is confirmed and filling vacancies for the remainder of the expired term. Amendments to the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 allow for the removal of Commission members for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. The Chairman can delegate powers to a panel of three or more members, with 3 members constituting a quorum. Two vacancies on the Commission will be filled by the President for terms expiring in 2006 and 2008. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to include a new section on the award of attorneys' fees and costs. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is amended to include a new section allowing employers with specific criteria to be awarded fees and expenses in certain proceedings. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 has been amended to allow employers meeting certain criteria to be awarded fees and expenses in proceedings under the Act. This provision applies to proceedings initiated after the enactment of the Act. The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 has been amended to allow employers meeting certain criteria to be awarded fees and expenses in proceedings under the Act. This provision applies to court proceedings for judicial review initiated after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. INDEPENDENT REVIEW. Amendment to the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 grants deference to the Commission's legal conclusions.
